description: A stocky, medium-sized parrot, the Jardine's is primarily green with black scalloping on the feathers, a black head, and red markings on the crown and wings. They are known for their steady temperament.
temperament: Intelligent, playful, and generally even-tempered. They are less demanding and prone to anxiety than African Greys, making them a more beginner-friendly Poicephalus.
loudness: Moderate. They are not known to be screamers, but they have a range of loud whistles and calls, especially when excited.
loudness_icon: <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="w-12 h-12 text-yellow-500" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" aria-hidden="true" role="img" aria-label="Moderate"><title>Moderate</title><path d="M7 9v6h4l5 5V4l-5 5H7zm9.5 2.5c0 .75-.38 1.41-.97 1.82v-3.64c.59.41.97 1.07.97 1.82zM14 8.25v7.5c1.18-.41 2-1.57 2-2.75s-.82-2.34-2-2.75z"></path></svg>
vocalization: Can be good talkers and are excellent at mimicking sounds and whistles. Their voice is high-pitched and clear.
dietaryNeeds: A high-quality pelleted diet should be the base, supplemented with fresh vegetables, and a small amount of fruit. Avoid high-fat diets.
healthPointers: Generally a hardy and robust species with a lifespan of 30+ years. Prone to respiratory issues like aspergillosis if kept in poor, damp conditions.
housing: Needs a roomy cage to accommodate their active nature. Minimum 30"W x 24"D x 48"H. Their moderate noise level makes them potentially suitable for apartments.
